docs.lead_paragraph: A dog's bugs can be worse than its bite. Cultures from 107 bites of human beings by infected dogs and cats turned up 152 kinds of bacteria, including 10 not previously known to infect people, a study found. There were an average of five kinds of germs per bite.

headline.main: Of Dog Bites, Cat Bites and People Bites

docs.abstract: Cultures from 107 bites of human beings by infected dogs and cats turns up 152 kinds of bacteria, including 10 not previously known to infect people; study finds there were average of five germs per bite; germs are not dangerous unless skin is broken (S)
docs.snippet: A dog's bugs can be worse than its bite.    Cultures from 107 bites of human beings by infected dogs and cats turned up 152 kinds of bacteria, including 10 not previously known to infect people, a study found. There were an average of five kinds of...

docs.lead_paragraph: I suspect that my most egregious lapse in healthful living is widely shared: Knowing that I might lose my teeth in the coming decades is not enough to get me to floss every night. I do endure thrice-yearly periodontal cleanings and admonishments to do a better job on a daily basis, but still that 18-inch strip of string does not always find its proper mark before the day is done. Even watching the misery my husband suffered in adjusting to dentures was not enough to sustain a nightly habit of flossing.

headline.main: Flossing Protects Far More Than the Teeth and Gums

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on importance of flossing one's teeth, not only to help prevent dental and periodontal problems, but to help keep bacteria in mouth under control; more than 400 species of bacteria live in human mouth; recent findings indicate that periodontal disease may precipitate or aggravate health problems elsewhere in body, some of them serious, and sometimes fatal (M)
docs.snippet: I suspect that my most egregious lapse in healthful living is widely shared: Knowing that I might lose my teeth in the coming decades is not enough to get me to floss every night. I do endure thrice-yearly periodontal cleanings and admonishments to...

docs.lead_paragraph: It was the confluence of two important events that made Carol Baxter start buying organic milk about five and a half years ago. Her oldest daughter had just turned 1 and soon would move from breast milk to cow's milk. And American dairy farmers had just received approval to inject their cows with recombinant bovine growth hormone, a genetically engineered hormone that increases milk production. Ms. Baxter, who lives in Palisades, N.Y., knew of environmental groups' claims that treated cows got more infections and needed more antibiotics, which could then enter their milk. And she learned that some scientists had raised the possibility of an increased cancer risk in people who drank the milk. ''Milk is such an important part of a child's diet,'' she said. ''I didn't want my child to be a guinea pig.''

headline.main: Fears Over Milk, Long Dismissed, Still Simmer

docs.abstract: Many consumers, skeptical of Government assurances about safety of milk, search out products that pledge that they do not use growth hormones or antibiotics; Canadian study and two studies published in 1998 rekindle longstanding worries about a possible increased risk of cancer from consuming milk from hormone-treated cows; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After surveying the body of scientific literature on lesbian health and holding workshops with researchers and clinicians, a panel of experts convened by the Institute of Medicine issued a report last week deploring the gaps in reliable information about lesbian health. The panel called for large-scale studies to counter rampant ''myths and misconceptions'' and to improve the quality of treatment lesbians are receiving. ''In the face of little empirical information, there are numerous beliefs and misconceptions about the health risks of lesbians that can affect their health outcome,'' said the report, called ''Lesbian Health: Current Assessment and Directions for the Future.''

headline.main: Fact, Fiction and the Health of Lesbians

docs.abstract: Panel of experts convened by Institute of Health issues report deploring gaps in reliable information about lesbian health (M)
docs.snippet: After surveying the body of scientific literature on lesbian health and holding workshops with researchers and clinicians, a panel of experts convened by the Institute of Medicine issued a report last week deploring the gaps in reliable information...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a bold but potentially frightening effort to turn one of the world's most virulent killers into a cure, scientists and biotechnology companies are trying to tame the AIDS virus and harness it to treat disease. The scientists say they have stripped the human immunodeficiency virus of its ability to cause disease, while leaving intact its ability to infect human cells. Such a crippled virus, they say, could be used to deliver genes into human cells for gene therapy.

headline.main: Scientists Enlist H.I.V. To Fight Other Ills

docs.abstract: Scientists and biotechnology companies are trying to tame AIDS virus and harness it to treat disease, including cancer, hemophilia and even AIDS itself; have stripped human immunodeficiency virus of its ability to cause disease, while leaving intact its ability to infect human cells; hope to use this ability to deliver genes into human cells for gene therapy; photo of Dr Inder M Verma of Salk Institute for Biological Studies (L)
docs.snippet: In a bold but potentially frightening effort to turn one of the world's most virulent killers into a cure, scientists and biotechnology companies are trying to tame the AIDS virus and harness it to treat disease.    The scientists say they have...

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. Businesses called oxygen bars, which provide customers with oxygen-rich air, are cropping up on the West Coast. Do these provide any health benefits? ALISHA BERGER It is well known that oxygen is a necessary nutrient for the function and health of every cell in the human body, and there is more than enough literature in favor of oxygen therapies. I have seen the practical effect of oxygen on the reversal of many diseases at my clinic, the Wilshire Medical Center.

headline.main: An Oxygen Rush: Good, Bad or Indifferent?

docs.abstract: Question of whether oxygen-rich air inhaled at oxygen bars, a new West Coast phenomenon, provide any health benefit is debated by Richard de Andrea, who thinks they do, and Dr Peter Jokl, who doubts it; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Q. Businesses called oxygen bars, which provide customers with oxygen-rich air, are cropping up on the West Coast. Do these provide any health benefits?   ALISHA BERGER      It is well known that oxygen is a necessary nutrient for the function and...

docs.lead_paragraph: For Jill Farwell, a Los Angeles public relations executive, pushing herself is almost as natural as breathing. So two years ago, when she discovered a passion for competitive rowing, she went full-throttle, training for up to two hours at a time on either an ergometer or in a boat. But after eight months of almost-daily workouts, her rowing pace began to slip -- not improve. ''I couldn't understand why my body couldn't match my drive,'' she said. Exhaustion became her constant companion. ''My muscles were tired all the time. I felt like my blood was running in slow motion,'' she recalled. One day after a particularly strenuous boat practice she had to lie down on the dock for half an hour.

headline.main: Law of Diminishing Returns for Athletes

docs.abstract: Exercising too much is becoming problem for small group of people, who suffer 'staleness syndrome' as a result; American College of Sports Medicine and United States Olympic Committee issue statement advising coaches and athletes to stay alert to symptoms of overtraining; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Flutes and their kin, including whistles, ocarinas, recorders and pipe organs, are among music's oldest and most versatile instruments. Yet science has long had trouble understanding all but the most elementary aspects of how they work. Now, however, researchers are starting to learn some of the secrets. In a way, science is glimpsing the soul of a very old machine.

headline.main: Ancient Instruments Yielding Secrets of Their Music

docs.abstract: Researchers reach deeper understanding of how flutes and other wind instruments work; new insights center on how jets, eddies and waves of air pressure come together at heart of such instruments to form complex vibrations heard as agreeable tones; drawings illustrate the physics behind music of some instruments (L)
docs.snippet: Flutes and their kin, including whistles, ocarinas, recorders and pipe organs, are among music's oldest and most versatile instruments. Yet science has long had trouble understanding all but the most elementary aspects of how they work.    Now,...

docs.lead_paragraph: A scientific advisory panel is asking the Food and Drug Administration to consider a basic question: Should a past travel itinerary help determine who is eligible to donate blood? The panel, concerned about ''mad cow disease,'' wants the agency to examine the possibility of barring blood donations from people who have lived in or visited Britain since 1980. Most reported cases of this fatal animal disease, and a human variant, have occurred in the British Isles.

headline.main: Keeping 'Mad Cow' Away From U.S. Blood Supply

docs.abstract: Scientific advisory panel asks FDA to consider whether people who have lived in or visited Britain since 1980 should be barred from giving blood to order protect blood recipients from mad cow disease; most reported cases of this fatal animal disease, and a human variant, have occurred in British isles; barring such blood donations could have huge impact on blood collection in United States; panel has no evidence that disease can be transmitted through blood, but does not want to be in position of not having taken seriously something that might turn into a problem in 10 to 20 years; photo (M)
